title: 113_hr3892
content:
The "Student Loan Borrowers' Bill of Rights Act of 2013" includes provisions for the dischargeability of student loans in bankruptcy cases and reinstatement of the 6-year statute of limitations for student loans. Subsection (a) of section 484A of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow institutions to pursue collection of refunds from students within a 6-year period, regardless of other limitations. Guaranty agencies with agreements with the Secretary can also take legal action within this timeframe. The Secretary or institutions with agreements can take legal action to collect amounts due from borrowers on loans made under specific parts within a 6-year period after default. The Secretary, Attorney General, or another Federal agency can file a suit to collect refunds or repayments from students or borrowers within a 6-year period after default. Prohibition of collecting student loans through offsets or wage garnishment. The amendment prohibits offset of Social Security benefits and tax refunds for payments certified by the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education. The amendment prohibits offset of Social Security benefits and tax refunds for payments certified by the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education. Any past-due legally enforceable debt owed to the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education shall not be subject to notification or reduction for such debt. The amendment prohibits garnishment of disposable pay for delinquent nontax debt owed to the Department of Education under a program administered by the Secretary of Education. TITLE II--BORROWER'S RIGHT TO REASONABLE AND FLEXIBLE REPAYMENT OPTIONS

SEC. 201. EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME FOR DISCHARGE OF STUDENT LOAN INDEBTEDNESS.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude discharged student loan indebtedness from gross income.

SEC. 202. 529 PLAN DISTRIBUTION FOR STUDENT LOAN PAYMENTS. The amendment to section 529(e)(3) allows for interest or principal payments on qualified education loans for designated beneficiaries. Conforming amendments are made to related sections in the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 203. INCLUSION OF PARENT PLUS LOANS IN REPAYMENT PROGRAMS. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Income Contingent Repayment Plan and the Income-Based Repayment program under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The changes include restrictions on the availability of repayment plans for borrowers of Federal Direct PLUS loans made on behalf of dependent students. Amendments are made to the Income Contingent Repayment Plan and the Income-Based Repayment program under the Higher Education Act of 1965, restricting the availability of repayment plans for borrowers of Federal Direct PLUS loans made on behalf of dependent students. The Pay As You Earn repayment plan is available to borrowers of Federal Direct PLUS loans made on behalf of dependent students and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans used to discharge the liability on such loans. Loan Forgiveness for Service in Areas of National Need is amended in the Federal Direct PLUS Loan and Federal Direct Consolidation Loan programs. SEC. 204. Amends the determination of adverse credit history under the Higher Education Act of 1965. TITLE III introduces prohibitions on suspensions of professional licenses and loss of access to transcripts for loan default under the same Act. SEC. 302 prohibits institutions from denying students access to transcripts or certifications due to loan default. SEC. 401 extends loan cancellation for public service employees to 5 years. Section 455(m) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow for 50 percent loan cancellation for eligible Federal Direct Loan borrowers in public service jobs after 5 years of repayment.
